selected_quotes: Potential role for skeletal muscle IL-15 in endurance training-induced muscle adaptation?
5 mins of research Endurance training enhances skeletal muscle in subjects ( …),

citation.abstract: Regular endurance exercise promotes metabolic and oxidative changes in skeletal muscle. Overexpression of interleukin-15 (IL-15) in mice exerts similar metabolic changes in muscle as seen with endurance exercise. Muscular IL-15 production has been shown to increase in mice after weeks of regular endurance running. With the present study we aimed to determine if muscular IL-15 production would increase in human male subjects following 12 weeks of endurance training. In two different studies we obtained plasma and muscle biopsies from young healthy subjects performing: (1) 12 weeks of ergometer cycling exercise five times per week with plasma and biopsies before and after the intervention, and (2) 3 h of ergometer cycling exercise with plasma and biopsies before and after the exercise bout and well into recovery. We measured changes in plasma IL-15, muscle IL-15 mRNA and IL-15 protein. Twelve weeks of regular endurance training induced a 40% increase in basal skeletal muscle IL-15 protein content (p < 0.01), but with no changes in either muscle IL-15 mRNA or plasma IL-15 levels. However, an acute bout of 3-h exercise did not show significant changes in muscle IL-15 or plasma IL-15 levels. The induction of muscle IL-15 protein in humans following a regular training period supports previous findings in mice and emphasizes the hypothesis of IL-15 taking part in skeletal muscle adaptation during training.
citation.title: Endurance training enhances skeletal muscle interleukin-15 in human male subjects

facebook.title: Endurance training enhances skeletal muscle interleukin-15 in human male subjects - Online First...
facebook.summary: Unsurprising: Endurance exercise increases the expression of IL-15 a myokine the injection of which has been shown to induce similar metabolic changes in skeletal muscle as endurance exercise... how come, if it is actually produced in response to endurance
